[[Memphis State University]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''John McConnell Wolfe Jr.''' (born April 21, 1954) is an [[United States|American]] [[Attorneys in the United States|attorney]] and [[Perennial candidate|perennial political candidate]]. He challenged [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]'s [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2012|2012 presidential nomination]]. He ultimately emerged as the most successful challenger, receiving the second-highest number of delegates (23) and popular votes (116,639).{{cite web | url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2011/dec/20/john-wolfe-qualifies-for-nh-primary/ | title=Chattanooga man John Wolfe running for president in New Hampshire | work=[[Chattanooga Times Free Press]] | date=December 20, 2011 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Carroll, Chris}}{{cite web | url=http://www.oakridger.com/newsnow/x587869255/John-Wolfe-running-for-President | title=John Wolfe running for President | publisher=OakRidger.com | date=March 4, 2012 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Tupper, Leean | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625213235/http://www.oakridger.com/newsnow/x587869255/John-Wolfe-running-for-President | archivedate=June 25, 2012 | df= }} ==Political campaigns== Wolfe made an unsuccessful bid in [[United States House of Representatives elections in Tennessee, 1998#District 3|1998]] for the Democratic congressional nomination in [[Tennessee's 3rd congressional district|Tennessee's 3rd district]]. In 2001, he ran for [[Mayor of Chattanooga, Tennessee]], and received 2.8% of the vote in that race, which was won by [[Bob Corker]]. In [[United States House of Representatives elections in Tennessee, 2002#District 3|2002]], he lost a second congressional bid in the 3rd District to then-[[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Zach Wamp]], and garnered 34% of the vote as the Democratic nominee. Wolfe faced Wamp again in a 2004 congressional rematch,{{cite web | url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2004/7/14/52852/Wolfe-Says-Wamp-Should-Abide-By-Term.aspx | title=Wolfe Says Wamp Should Abide By Term Limit, PAC Pledges | work=[[The Chattanoogan]] | date=July 14, 2004 | accessdate=March 28, 2012}} and was again defeated, this time acquiring 33% of the vote. In 2007, he ran unsuccessfully in a [[special election]] for a [[Tennessee Senate|Tennessee State Senate]] seat.{{cite web | url=http://www.chattanoogan.com/2007/9/11/113149/Wolfe-Whittaker-Take-Campaigns-To-JFK.aspx | title=Wolfe, Whittaker Take Campaigns To JFK Club | work=[[The Chattanoogan]] | date=September 11, 2007 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Frank, Judy}} Wolfe was fined $10,000 in 2008 after he failed to file a fourth-quarter campaign finance disclosure report for his 2007 State Senate campaign with the state as required by law. Until it is paid, Wolfe is barred from qualifying for election in any [[Tennessee]] state or local office. In [[United States House of Representatives elections in Tennessee, 2010#District 3|2010]], he ran for Congress in Tennessee's 3rd district,{{cite web | url=http://www.oakridger.com/news/x2002277098/Wolfe-Conservative-Fleischmann-radical | title=Wolfe: Conservative, Fleischmann 'radical'? | publisher=OakRidger.com | date=September 10, 2010 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Huotari, John | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120707214348/http://www.oakridger.com/news/x2002277098/Wolfe-Conservative-Fleischmann-radical | archivedate=July 7, 2012 | df= }} and lost to [[Chuck Fleischmann]] 57%-28%.{{cite web | url=http://www.myfoxmemphis.com/dpp/news/local/110310-results-summary-of-tennessee-races | title=Results Summary of Tennessee Races | publisher=MyFox Memphis | date=November 3, 2010 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929115712/http://www.myfoxmemphis.com/dpp/news/local/110310-results-summary-of-tennessee-races | archivedate=September 29, 2011 | df= }} Wolfe has also made two runs for the Democratic presidential primaries, in 2012 and in 2016. ===Congressional campaigns=== ====1998 congressional campaign==== In 1998 Wolfe ran, unsuccessfully, in the Democratic primary for [[Tennessee's 3rd congressional district]]. ====2002 congressional campaign==== {{Infobox U.S. federal election campaign | committee = John McConnel Wolfe Jr for Congress | logo = | campaign = [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2002#Tennessee|2002 US congressional elections, Tennessee's 3rd district]] | candidate = John Wolfe Jr. }} In the 2002 race for [[Tennessee's 3rd congressional district|Tennessee's 3rd district]], Wolfe was the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] challenger to incumbent [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Zach Wamp]]. Wolfe ultimately lost to Wamp. Below is the result of the general election {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- style="background-color:#E9E9E9" ! colspan="7" | 2002 election for Tennessee's 3rd congressional district{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/2004election.pdfx|title=STATISTICS OF THE PRESIDENTIAL AND CONGRESSIONAL ELECTION OF NOVEMBER 2, 2004|website=clerk.house.gov|accessdate=June 27, 2016}} |- bgcolor="#EEEEEE" align="center" ! colspan=2 style="width: 15em" |Party !Candidate ! style="width: 5em" |Votes ! style="width: 7em" |Percentage |- ! style="background-color:#FF3333; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Republican Party of Tennessee|Republican]] |[[Zach Wamp]] | align="right" |112,254 | align="right" |64.54% |- ! style="background-color:#3333FF; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Tennessee Democratic Party|Democratic]] | John Wolfe Jr | align="right" |58,824 | align="right" |33.82% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | William C. Teague Jr. '' treasurer'' }} In 2004 Wolfe again was nominated to run against Wamp for Tennessee's 3rd congressional district. Wolfe lost again. Wolfe, however, was able to garner a greater number and a greater percent of the vote in 2004 than he had in 2002. He ultimately lost to [[Chuck Fleischmann]] 57% to 28%. Wolfe faced three other candidates for the Democratic nomination. The three other candidates on the August 2010 Democratic primary ballots were Alicia Mitchel of Oak Ridge, Brenda Freeman Short of East Ridge, and Brent Staton of Chattanooga.{{cite web |title=2010 U.S. House Democratic Primary by County |work=Tennessee Secretary of State – Election Results |date=August 5, 2010 |url=http://sharetngov.tnsosfiles.com.s3.amazonaws.com/sos/election/results/2010-08/DemUSHouseCounty.pdf |accessdate=2017-10-06 }} Several candidates had dropped-out ahead of the primary, including Tom Humphrey,{{cite web |last=Humphrey |first=Tom |title=Congressional Candidate Money Notes |date=15 October 2009 |work=Humphrey on the Hill |via=[[Knoxville News Sentinel]] |url=http://knoxblogs.com/humphreyhill/2009/10/15/congressional_candidate_money |accessdate=2017-10-06}}{{cite web |last=Lance |first=Joe |title=What Kind of Democrat Will Win the Third District Primary? |date=28 September 2009 |work=[[chattarati.com]] |url=http://chattarati.com/2009/09/28/what-kind-of-democrat-will-win-the-third-district-primary |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091006180837/http://chattarati.com/2009/09/28/what-kind-of-democrat-will-win-the-third-district-primary |archivedate=2009-10-06 |accessdate=2017-10-06 }} Paula Flowers of Oak Ridge (a former member of Governor [[Phil Bredesen]]'s cabinet), and Brent Benedict (who was the 2006 Democratic nominee for the 3rd district).[http://www.allbusiness.com/government/elections-politics-campaigns-elections/13234988-1.html 3rd District hopefuls tout finances], AllBusiness.com website, attributed to ''Chattanooga Times Free Press'', October 17, 2009 Below is the result of the general election: {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- style="background-color:#E9E9E9" ! colspan="7" | 2010 election for Tennessee's 3rd congressional district{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/2010election.pdf|title=STATISTICS OF THE CONGRESSIONAL ELECTION OF NOVEMBER 2, 2010|website=clerk.house.gov|accessdate=June 27, 2016}} |- bgcolor="#EEEEEE" align="center" ! colspan=2 style="width: 15em" |Party !Candidate ! style="width: 5em" |Votes ! style="width: 7em" |Percentage |- ! style="background-color:#FF3333; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Republican Party of Tennessee|Republican]] |[[Chuck Fleischmann]] | align="right" | 92,032 | align="right" | 56.79% |- ! style="background-color:#3333FF; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Tennessee Democratic Party|Democratic]] | John Wolfe Jr | align="right" | 45,387 | align="right" | 28.00% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | Savas T. Kyriakidis | align="right" | 17,077 | align="right" | 10.54% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | Mark DeVol | align="right" | 5,773 | align="right" | 3.56% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | Don Barkman | align="right" | 811 | align="right" | 0.50% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | Gregory C. Goodwin | align="right" | 380 | align="right" | 0.24% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | Robert Humphries | align="right" | 380 | align="right" | 0.24% |- ! style="background-color:#DDDDDD; width: 3px" | | style="width: 130px" | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | Mo Kiah | align="right" | 216 | align="right" | 0.13% |-bgcolor="#EEEEEE" | colspan="3" align="right" | '''Totals''' | align="right" | '''162,056''' | align="right" | '''100.00%''' |} ===Presidential campaigns=== ====2012 presidential campaign==== {{Infobox U.S. federal election campaign | committee = Wolfe 2012 | logo = John Wolfe Jr. logo 2012 (transparent).png | campaign = [[United States presidential election, 2012]] | candidate = John Wolfe Jr. | cand_id = C00518753 | fec_date = | affiliation = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] | headquarters = 3815 Forest Highlands Drive, Chattanooga, TN 37415 | key_people = | receipts = | slogan = | homepage = | status = }} {{commons category|John Wolfe Jr. presidential campaign, 2012}} {{Wikinews|Wikinews interviews John Wolfe, Democratic Party presidential challenger to Barack Obama}} [[File:John Wolfe Jr. ballot access 2012.svg|thumb|Map representing the ballot access of Wolfe's 2012 campaign
'''Legend:'''
{{legend|#008000|On ballot}}{{legend|#99FF99|Write-in}}{{legend|#D3D3D3|Not on ballot}}]] [[File:Second-place candidates in the Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2012.svg|thumb|Map of second-place candidates in the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2012|2012 Democratic presidential primaries]]
'''Legend:'''
{{legend|#FF8C00 |[[Keith Russell Judd]]}} {{legend|#FF0000|[[Ron Paul]]}} {{legend|#00FFFF |[[Darcy Richardson]]}} {{legend|#800080 |John Wolfe Jr.}} {{legend|#800000 |[[Randall Terry]]}} {{legend|#808080|Uncommitted/other}} {{legend|#000000|No second-place finisher}} {{legend|#D3D3D3|No primary held/ no info available}}]] =====Platform===== Wolfe supports a return to the [[Glass-Steagall Act]] to separate speculative activity from commercial banking. He favors the use of [[Anti-Trust Laws]] to reduce the size of "megabanks," and proposes a tax on [[financial derivatives]]. He also proposes an "Alternate Federal Reserve" which would loan to community banks, small business, and individuals, as opposed to the [[Federal Reserve Bank]], which, Wolfe contends, serves primarily the interests of the six largest banks. Wolfe is also a critic of the [[Affordable Care Act]], saying that it is oriented primarily toward helping the insurance and pharmaceutical companies. Instead, he supports [[Medicare for All]].[http://www.johnwolfeforamerica2012.com/content/Issues/Issues.asp John Wolfe on the Issues] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503041420/http://www.johnwolfeforamerica2012.com/content/Issues/Issues.asp |date=2012-05-03 }}, campaign website =====Reception===== Wolfe took part in the New Hampshire "lesser known candidates forum" in December 2011.{{cite web | url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20111220/NEWS0605/712209967 | title=Lesser-known candidates bring colorful campaigns to St. Anselm | work=[[New Hampshire Union Leader]] | date=December 20, 2011 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Ríos, Simón | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308183649/http://www.unionleader.com/article/20111220/NEWS0605/712209967# | archive-date=2012-03-08 | dead-url=yes | df= }} He qualified for the ballot in the [[New Hampshire Democratic primary, 2012|New Hampshire Democratic primary]], in which he received 246 votes, 0.4% of the vote total. In addition to [[New Hampshire]], he qualified for presidential primary ballots in the states of [[Missouri]],{{cite web | url=http://www.thegreenpapers.com/P12/MO-D | title=Missouri Democrat: Presidential nominating process | work=The Green Papers | accessdate=March 28, 2012}} [[Louisiana]]{{cite web | url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2012/03/rick_santorums_louisiana_prima.html | title=Louisiana primary makes its mark | work=[[The Times-Picayune]] | date=March 26, 2012 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Tilove, Jonathan}} and [[Arkansas]].{{cite web | url=http://www.wdef.com/news/state/story/Democrat-files-in-Arkansas-to-run-against-Obama/9DF5YgVYKEqjw8PmEsfZow.cspx | title=Democrat files in Arkansas to run against Obama | publisher=[[Associated Press]] | work=[[WDEF-TV]] | date=March 1, 2012 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In the [[Louisiana Democratic primary, 2012|Louisiana primary]], Wolfe polled 11.83%{{cite web | url=http://www.ballot-access.org/2012/03/27/little-known-democratic-presidential-candidate-may-have-polled-enough-votes-in-louisiana-for-a-delegate/ | title=Little-Known Democratic Presidential Candidate May Have Polled Enough Votes in Louisiana for a Delegate | work=[[Ballot Access News]] | date=March 27, 2012 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=[[Richard Winger|Winger, Richard]]}} which qualified him to earn a minimum of three [[Delegate#Presidential conventions|delegates]] to the [[2012 Democratic National Convention]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2012/03/democratic_challenger_to_barac.html | title=Democratic challenger to Barack Obama picks off delegates in Louisiana | work=[[The Times-Picayune]] | date=March 27, 2012 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Tilove, Jonathan}}{{cite web | url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2012/03/fresh_off_success_in_la_democr.html | title=John Wolfe faces challenge to place on Texas ballot | work=[[The Times-Picayune]] | date=March 28, 2012 | accessdate=March 28, 2012 | author=Tilove, Jonathan}} Following the primary, officials of the [[Democratic Party of Louisiana]] announced that Wolfe was ineligible for the delegates he had apparently won because, according to the party officials, Wolfe had not properly complied with the party's qualification requirements.{{cite web | url=http://www.wrcbtv.com/story/17525058/john-wolfe-cries-foul-in-louisiana-primary | title=John Wolfe cries foul in Louisiana primary | publisher=[[WRCB]] | work=[[Chattanooga Times Free Press]] | date=April 18, 2012 | accessdate=May 2, 2012 | author=Pare, Mike}}{{cite web | url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2012/04/president_obama_will_clinch_re.html | title=President Obama will clinch renomination Tuesday, but it may not be unanimous | work=The Times-Picayune | date=April 23, 2012 | accessdate=May 2, 2012 | author=Tilove, Jonathan}} In response, Wolfe filed a lawsuit against the party, disputing the claim that he did not qualify to receive the delegates. Following incumbent President [[Barack Obama]]'s narrower-than-expected primary win in [[West Virginia]], where convicted felon [[Keith Russell Judd]] finished a strong second as a [[protest vote]], press began to speculate on the possibility of Wolfe, who lacks Judd's criminal record, possibly contending and even winning the state of Arkansas.[[William Kristol|Kristol, William]] (May 9, 2012). [http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/arkansass-moment_644283.html Arkansas's moment: John Wolfe for president?] ''The Weekly Standard''. Retrieved May 16, 2012.Pappas, Alex (May 16, 2012). [http://dailycaller.com/2012/05/16/obscure-ark-candidate-optimistic-after-poll-shows-him-in-competitive-race-with-obama/ Obscure candidate in Ark. optimistic after poll shows him in competitive race with Obama]. ''The Daily Caller''. Retrieved May 16, 2012. A poll conducted by [[Hendrix College]] of Democrats in [[Arkansas's 4th congressional district]] showed Wolfe within seven points of Obama there.Brock, Roby (May 15, 2012). [http://talkbusiness.net/2012/05/obama-in-for-a-battle-in-the-fourth-romney-on-cruise-control/ Obama In For A Battle In The Fourth, Romney On Cruise Control]. ''TalkBusiness''. Retrieved May 16, 2012. Wolfe finished second in that primary, garnering 41.6% of the vote.Parker, Suzi (May 23, 2012). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/23/us-usa-campaign-kentucky-idUSBRE84L1FM20120523 Obama struggles in Kentucky, Arkansas primaries]. ''Reuters''. Retrieved May 23, 2012. He filed a legal action to have delegates seated at the [[2012 Democratic National Convention]].[http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/05/26/candidate-who-won-42-percent-in-arkansas-democratic-primary-sues-for-his/print Candidate who won 42 percent in Arkansas Democratic primary sues for his delegates] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526224936/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/05/26/candidate-who-won-42-percent-in-arkansas-democratic-primary-sues-for-his/print |date=2012-05-26 }}. ''Fox News''. Retrieved May 26, 2012. Wolfe contested the Texas Democratic primary, garnering 5.05 percent of the vote, winning one county ([[Borden County, Texas|Borden County]]) and tying in another ([[Sherman County, Texas|Sherman County]]). No delegates were at stake in the contest.[https://archive.is/20120906083859/http://www.myfoxdfw.com/story/18652017/wolfe-fails-to-repeat-arkansas-success-as-obama-easily-wins-texas-primary Wolfe fails to repeat Arkansas success as Obama easily wins Texas primary]. {{Infobox criminal | name = Kenneth McGriff | image_name = Kenneth McGriff.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|9|19|}} | birth_place = [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | alias = Supreme | charge = [[Illegal drug trade|Drug trafficking]], [[murder]] | conviction_penalty = Life in prison | conviction_status = Incarcerated | occupation = Mob boss, [[drug lord]] | spouse = | parents = | }} '''Kenneth "Supreme" McGriff''' (born September 19, 1960) is a convicted American [[Illegal drug trade|drug trafficker]] and [[organized crime]] figure.
McGriff came to prominence in the early 1980s when he formed his own [[Crack cocaine|crack]]-distributing organization which he called the [[Supreme Team (gang)|Supreme Team]] based in the [[South Jamaica, Queens|South Jamaica]] section of [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Under McGriff's leadership, the gang's numbers swelled to the hundreds and came to control the crack cocaine trade in the [[Baisley Park Houses]], the neighborhood where McGriff was raised.
In 1987, McGriff was arrested following a joint state and federal investigation and in 1989 pleaded guilty to engaging in a [[Continuing Criminal Enterprise]]. He was sentenced to 12 years' incarceration. McGriff was released from prison on parole in early 1994 after serving approximately seven years of his sentence. He was sent back to prison on parole violations by year's end, and served another 2½ years' incarceration before being released in 1997.
McGriff is alleged to have had a hand in the 2002 murder of [[Run-DMC]] member [[Jam Master Jay]], and was convicted of ordering the 2001 killing of [[Mobb Deep]] affiliate E-Moneybags (real name Eric Smith).<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/02/nyregion/02mcgriff.html | work=The New York Times | first=William K. | last=Rashbaum | title=Man Convicted in 2 Killings; U.S. to Pursue the Death Penalty | date=February 2, 2007}}</ref> Federal authorities also accused him in connection with the attempted murder of rapper [[50 Cent]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/09/07/entertainment/main822172.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Feds Lay Out Alleged 50 Cent Plot | date=September 7, 2005}}</ref> Persistent rumors suggest that McGriff felt 50 Cent had exposed too much of the drug kingpin in [[Jamaica, Queens]], and others involved in the drug trade through the lyrics of his song "[[Ghetto Qu'ran (Forgive Me)|Ghetto Qu'ran]]" released in 2000.
On February 1, 2007, McGriff was convicted of [[Contract killing|murder-for-hire]] at a Federal court in the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York|Eastern District of New York]] on charges that he paid $50,000 to have two rivals (Eric Smith and "Big Nose" Troy Singleton) gunned down in 2001.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,251209,00.html | work=Fox News | title=Hip-Hop Drug Lord Kenneth 'Supreme' McGriff Gets Life Without Parole for Slayings | date=February 9, 2007}}</ref> The jury deliberated for five days before finding McGriff guilty of murder conspiracy and drug trafficking. On February 9, 2007, the same jury sentenced McGriff to life in prison. Throughout this case he was defended by a court-appointed attorney because nearly all of his assets had been seized.
McGriff began serving his life sentence at [[ADX Florence]], the federal [[supermax prison]] in [[Colorado]], but in 2011, was transferred to the [[United States Penitentiary, Lee]], a high-security federal prison in [[Pennington Gap, Virginia]].<ref>[http://betamericangangster.blogspot.com/2010/12/season-two-episode-10-kenneth-supreme.html A blog "open to invited readers only"]</ref><ref>[http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&LastName=mcgriff&Middle=&FirstName=kenneth&Race=B&Sex=M&Age=&x=332&y=290 McGriff's entry at the US Bureau of Prisons]</ref>

{{distinguish|Corihor}}
'''Korihor''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|oʊ|r|ɪ|h|ɔːr}})<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «kō´rĭ-hōr»</ref> is an [[anti-christ]] described in {{lds|Alma|alma|30}} in the [[Book of Mormon]].
==Life==
Korihor is directly referred to in the Book of Mormon as an [[antichrist|Anti-Christ]], because he claimed there will be no [[Christ]]. Korihor was able to preach his views to the people because of the land's freedom of religion. These teachings alarmed the clerical government in [[Zarahemla]], who felt that his views were dangerous to their society, as people had begun to ignore the laws of the land (which were based on the religious beliefs of their society). He attempted to preach to the people of [[Ammon]], but the residents had kicked him out of [[Jershon]]. He also tried preaching in Gideon and he was arrested; before a high priest, during a hearing for his apparent [[blasphemy]] and for causing social discord, Korihor offered a speech in his own defense. Korihor was turned over to higher authority and later got into an argument with the chief judge and governor, [[Alma the Younger|Alma]] regarding the existence of God. Alma responded to Korihor's arguments, stating that all things testified that there is a God. Korihor finally demanded that Alma show him a sign from God or he, Korihor, would not believe in God. This culminated in Korihor being miraculously rendered deaf and mute, upon which Korihor confessed, in writing: {{quote|...I always knew that there was a God. But behold, the devil hath deceived me; for he appeared unto me in the form of an angel, and said unto me: Go and reclaim this people, for they have all gone astray after an unknown God. And he said unto me: There is no God; yea, and he taught me that which I should say.<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|52|53}}</ref>}}
Korihor begged for forgiveness, but Alma, sensing that Korihor would go back to his wicked ways, cast Korihor out. Korihor became a beggar and was later trampled to death by the [[Zoramites]], a group who had separated themselves from the main [[Nephite]] society.
== Teachings ==
Korihor's statements provide explicit arguments for atheism, which have been categorized as arguments for agnosticism, empiricism, secular humanism, and relativism.<ref>{{citation |last= Riddle |first= Chauncey |title= Korihor: The Arguments of Apostasy |url= http://maxwellinstitute.byu.edu/publications/transcripts/?id=45 |publisher= [[Neal A. Maxwell Institute for Religious Scholarship]], [[BYU]] |accessdate= 4 April 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{citation |last= Lund |first= Gerald N. |authorlink= Gerald N. Lund |date=July 1992 |title= Countering Korihor's Philosophy |url= http://www.lds.org/ensign/1992/07/countering-korihors-philosophy?lang=eng |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] |publisher= LDS Church }}</ref> Perhaps because of the direct treatment that Korihor gives the topic of atheism, his words have been cited by skeptics as exemplary, while devotees cite his teachings in an attempt to inoculate their audiences against similar heresy.<ref>{{citation |last= Warner |first= C. Terry |authorlink= C. Terry Warner |title= An Open Letter to Students: On Having Faith and Thinking for Yourself |url= http://www.lds.org/new-era/1971/11/an-open-letter-to-students-on-having-faith-and-thinking-for-yourself?lang=eng |journal= [[New Era (magazine)|New Era]] |publisher= LDS Church }}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Chapter 29: Alma 30–31 |url= http://www.lds.org/manual/book-of-mormon-teacher-manual/chapter-29?lang=eng |work= Book of Mormon Teacher Manual: Religion 121-122 |publisher= [[Institute of Religion|Institute program]], [[Church Educational System]], LDS Church |year= 2009}}</ref>
Korihor's argument was two-fold. First, that "ye cannot know of things which ye do not see", from which he extrapolated that there is no fairness or unfairness, no crime or sin, no cause for shame, and no eternal consequence of actions.<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|15|18}}</ref> In the absence of sin, the need for an atoning sacrifice<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|12|17}}</ref> and the ordinances and religious participation to connect people to that atoning sacrifice<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|23}}</ref> are obviated, and followers are instead encouraged to "look up with boldness", "enjoy their rights and privileges", and "make use of that which is their own".<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|20|27|28}}</ref> Second, Korihor hypothesizes that the only reason for perpetuation of orthodox beliefs is "a foolish and vain hope"<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|13}}</ref> on the part of believers, and, on the part of priests and teachers, a desire "to usurp power and authority over [the people]"<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|23}}</ref> and "keep them down, even as it were in bondage, that ye may glut yourselves with the labors of their hands".<ref>{{lds|Alma|alma|30|27}}</ref>
== Possible origin of the name == [[File:KingHerihorAdoreOsiris.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Herihor or Kherihor, who Hugh Nibley relates to the name Korihor.]]
[[Hugh Nibley]] relates the name to Egypt,<ref>[[Hugh Nibley|Nibley, Hugh]] & Hummel, Sharman Bookwalter (ed.) ''Nibley's Commentary on the Book of Mormon, Vol. 1'' (2013), ASIN: B00GFY0GUO</ref> and states:
:"The first high priest [of the twenty-first dynasty in Egypt] was called Korihor, and his son was called Piankhi - two Book of Mormon names."
Nibley relates Korihor's name to [[Herihor|Kherihor]], a high priest at [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]].<ref>''Lehi in the Desert'', p. 27. Nibley's source for the Egyptian name is [[Hermann Ranke]], ''Die Agyptischen Personennamen'' ["The Egyptian Personal Names"], Gluckstadt: Augustin, 1935.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

Welch | title = The Legal Cases in the Book of Mormon | place = Provo, Utah | publisher = [[Brigham Young University Press]]; [[Neal A. Maxwell Institute for Religious Scholarship]] | year = 2011 | isbn = 0842527125 | oclc = 232358237 | url = http://publications.maxwellinstitute.byu.edu/book/the-legal-cases-in-the-book-of-mormon/ }} *{{cite book |url= https://rsc.byu.edu/archived/book-mormon-alma-testimony-word/7-anti-christ-book-mormon-face-may-be-strange-voice |contribution= An Anti-Christ in the Book of Mormon--The Face May Be Strange, but the Voice Is Familiar |authorlink= Gerald N. Lund |last= Lund|first= Gerald N. |page= 107–28 |title= The Book of Mormon: Alma, the Testimony of the Word |editor1-last= Nyman |editor1-first= Monte S. |editor1-link= Monte S. Nyman |editor2-first= Charles D., Jr. |editor2-last= Tate |place= Provo, Utah |publisher= [[Religious Studies Center]], [[Brigham Young University]] |year= 1992 |isbn= 0-8849-4841-2 |oclc= }}

{{Orphan|date=September 2016}}
'''Laura Caller''' (1915–1988)
Union lawyer, defender of peasants and politicians.
She was born in [[Cusco]] in a home frequented by intellectuals of the city due to the activities of her father, a journalist and writer.
She studied primary and started secondary school in the Colegio María Auxiliadora, Cusco, where she was expelled at age twelve for resistance to the "almost monastic" rules. She entered the College of Sciences Cusco, exclusively for men, with the support of famous Cusco intellectual [[:es:José Uriel García|José Uriel García]].
In 1938 she came to [[Lima]] to study at university, intending to study agronomy, but decided on Law at the [[National University of San Marcos]], where she majored in Agricultural Law.
Her professional work was dedicated from the start to the defence of the rights of peasant communities, and political prisoners. Her fight against the exploitation of the defenceless defined her political ideas for socialism.
Her reputation for social advocacy dates back to the 40s and 50s, however it was in 1963, when defending 200 political prisoners confined in the island prison of [[El Frontón]], that she achieved notoriety because it was the first time a woman had faced a military tribunal as a defender. In 1966 she helped get [[Hugo Blanco (politician)|Hugo Blanco]] acquitted of the death penalty and became internationally known.
In 1975 she endorsed the case of the rural community of [[Huayanay]], on the heights of [[Huancavelica]], who had killed the village leader in the main square, according to their ancestral customs. They were exonerated by the Velasco government, but later some of them were imprisoned in Lima.
She never married because she considered herself married to the law and led a life of austerity and sacrifice.
As a social activist she travelled around the country visiting rural communities and remote mining camps. She and her famous poncho were seen in the villages as a sign of hope. She herself was imprisoned for the crime of defending the poor.
Campaigner for women's votes and defender of peasants, she never obtained a seat in Parliament, but in 1980 joined the board of the [[FOCEP]] political group as vice-president.
In 1985 she had a leg amputated due to gangrene, a result of diabetes. Months later she travelled to [[Cuba]] for rehabilitation from which she returned with a prosthesis to continue working in the defence of the needy. She died in Lima on March 15, 1988 due to a worsening of her disease, 48 hours before she was due to receive an award from the Ministry of Labour.
She is commemorated by name in the village of Laura Caller, San Luis District, Peru.
<ref name="heroinas">{{cite web|url=http://www.heroinas.net/2012/04/laura-caller-de-peru.html|publisher=heroinas.net|title=Heroínas: Laura Caller de Peru|accessdate=2016-09-18}}</ref>

'''Lisa Kekaula''' (born July 31, 1967 in [[Los Angeles, California]]) is the [[lead singer]] of American "[[Rock (music)|rock]] 'n' [[Soul music|soul]]" band '''[[The Bellrays]]'''.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p380250/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: The BellRays|last=Loftus|first=Johnny|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref>
Kekaula was born to an [[African-American]] mother, Linda and [[Native Hawaiian]] father, Alan Kekaula in Los Angeles, California, although the family continued to grow and relocated to suburban [[Moreno Valley]], California. While there, Kekaula began to immerse herself in singing and had her first appearance in a talent show at Edgemont Elementary School. She graduated from [[Moreno Valley High School (California)|Moreno Valley High School]] and then from the [[University of California, Riverside]].
Since 1990, Kekaula has been vocalist with [[the Bellrays]].
From 2003 to 2007, Kekaula joined a cast of vocalists guesting at live performances by the surviving members of [[the MC5]].<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/still-kicking-out-the-jams-484360.html</ref>
Kekaula has featured on two singles by British [[house music]] band [[Basement Jaxx]], most famously "[[Good Luck (Basement Jaxx song)|Good Luck]]", the tracks "Realizer" and "High and Low" from the 2004 album ''[[Legion of Boom (album)|Legion of Boom]]'' by [[The Crystal Method]], and "Talkin' in My Sleep" from [[The Bloody Beetroots]]' first studio album, ''[[Romborama]]''. She has also been featured on the most recent [[The Legendary Tigerman]] album, ''Femina''.
In 2014, Kekaula contributed vocals to two tracks for the ''[[Re-Licked]]'' album of [[Iggy and the Stooges]] songs re-recorded by former Stooges guitarist [[James Williamson (musician)|James Williamson]]. The songs were also released as a 7" single.<ref>http://www.premierguitar.com/articles/21056-ear-to-the-ground-james-williamson-and-lisa-kekaulas-i-gotta-right</ref> In 2016, Kekaula and Williamson collaborated again, releasing a single in aid of a [[Hawaii]]an homeless charity.<ref>http://hpr2.org/post/helping-hand-stooges-james-williamson-benefit-single-project-hawaii</ref>
Kekaula is married to Robert Vennum, also of the Bellrays; they have one daughter, Twylla. In 2014, Kekaula and Vennum released an album under the name Lisa and the Lips.
== Basement Jaxx discography == *"Good Luck" (2004) #12 UK, #22 Australia (also featured in the Japanese CG film ''[[Appleseed (film)|Appleseed]]'') *"U Don't Know Me" (2005) #26 UK, #56 Australia *"Stay Close" (2009) featured on the ''[[Scars (Basement Jaxx album)|Scars]]'' album

{{refimprove|date=April 2014}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of people on the cover of ''Attitude'' magazine}} This is a list of people who have appeared on the front cover of ''[[Attitude (magazine)|Attitude]]'', a gay lifestyle magazine that is printed monthly in the United Kingdom. == Statistics == Often, the cover is of a straight celebrity gay people worship at the time. As of May 2010, attitude created 151 magazines of which 106 covers have been dedicated to straight celebrities or politicians. Only 45 covers have been dedicated to gay celebrities. The longest stretch straight celebrities have not appeared on the cover is two months. Editor Matthew Todd has claimed has suggested there are not enough famous gay people to have them on the cover constantly and has made a point of putting celebrities on the cover such as Beth Ditto '''Marc-Antoine Jullien''', called '''Jullien fils''', (born [[Paris]], March 10, 1775 – died there April 4, 1848) was a [[France|French]] [[French Revolution|revolutionary]] and man of letters.
==Life== Son of [[Marc Antoine Jullien]], deputy from [[Drôme]] in the [[National Convention]], he entered the [[Collège de Navarre]] in 1785; his studies were interrupted by the beginning of the Revolution. Encouraged by his ardently patriotic mother, Rosalie Ducrolay, named "Madame Jullien", he attempted a career in journalism, in 1790 becoming a collaborator on the ''[[Journal du Soir]]''. The following year, he became a member of the [[Jacobin Club]], in which he became an opponent of war.
In the spring of 1792, Jullien was sent to [[London]] by the [[Marquis de Condorcet]], at the time president of the ''[[comité diplomatique]]'' of the [[Legislative Assembly (France)|Legislative Assembly]]. There he served as a student-diplomat, becoming an intermediary between the more liberal English factions and the [[Girondist]]s. Among those he met there were [[Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord|Talleyrand]] and [[Philip Stanhope, 5th Earl of Chesterfield|Lord Stanhope]]. Returning to France that autumn, he was named ''aide-commissaire''m and then ''commissaire des guerres'', of the army of the [[Pyrenees]], in January 1793. He was soon transferred to [[Tarbes]] "due to age". He rejoined the army of the Pyrenees on April 16, entering Paris with them on August 4.
Jullien then became a protégé of [[Maximilien Robespierre|Robespierre]], and was sent by the [[Committee of Public Safety]] on a mission to several Atlantic ports, beginning on September 10, 1793. Charged with ensuring surveillance of the military situation and of [[Jacobin (politics)|Jacobin]] propaganda, he attempted to gain for himself a rapport with public feeling. In [[Nantes]], on February 4, 1794, he wrote a letter to Robespierre in which he denounced [[Jean-Baptiste Carrier|Carrier]]. At [[Bordeaux]], he stood in opposition to [[Jean-Lambert Tallien]] and his mistress, [[Thérésa Cabarrús]]. He left Bordeaux to return to Paris on April 24, 1794; there he was named to the Executive Committee on Public Instruction. On May 18, he returned to Bordeaux, to purify the municipality and the Jacobin Club and seek out hidden Girondists among the deputies.
Jullien would likely have become a major player in the Revolution had it not been for the execution, by [[guillotine]], of Robespierre in July 1794. Made destitute, he was arrested on August 10 and sent to prison; he would be held at the ''maison de santé'' of Notre-Dame-des-Champs, and would testify at Carrier's trial. He disavowed his association with Robespierre and was released, through the intervention of his father, on October 14, 1795. Ten days later, the insurrection of [[13 Vendémiaire]] was stopped.
Jullien next became one of the founders of the [[Club du Panthéon]], returning to journalism with the creation of ''[[L'Orateur plébéien]]'', a democratic and moderate pamphlet, with [[Ève Demaillot]] and [[Jean-Jacques Leuliette]]. On March 13, 1796, [[Philippe-Antoine Merlin de Douai|Merlin de Douai]] helped him enter the [[Ministère de la Police]], where he became responsible for lists of emigrans. He soon became suspected of [[François-Noël Babeuf|Babouvist]] sympathies, and was forced to hide after the discovery of the Conspiracy of Equals in May 1796; he reappeared in October of the same year.
Jullien next joined the [[Army of Italy (France)|Army of Italy]], becoming a writer for its mail service from August to November 1797. He then accompanied [[Napoleon I]], in May 1798, on his journey to [[Egypt]]. There he became ill, and returned to France with [[Louis Bonaparte]]. Becoming well, he entered the service of general [[Jean Étienne Championnet|Championnet]], becoming an adviser on December 28, 1798. Among the initiators of the [[Neapolitan Republic (Napoleonic)|Neapolitan Republic]], he became secretary general to Championnet's provisional government on January 26, 1799. He was quickly recalled by the [[French Directory|Directory]], and was arrested on February 24. On March 12 he stood before a [[military tribunal]], but was freed by the [[Coup of 30 Prairial Year VII]] on June 18.
Accommodating the coup of [[18 Brumaire]] to satisfaction, Jullien proposed a plan to unify the Italian states in July 1800. Immediately becoming indignant at anti-Jacobin proscriptions, following the [[Plot of the Rue Saint-Nicaise]] he was relegated to handling administrative functions in Paris. He received the cross of the [[Légion d'honneur]] in 1803. After a visit to [[Anne Louise Germaine de Staël|Madame de Staël]] at [[Chaumont-sur-Loire]], through which he raised Napoleon's suspicions, he was sent to the [[Kingdom of Italy (Napoleonic)|Kingdom of Italy]] in 1810; while passing through [[Yverdon]], he became acquainted with the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[pedagogue]] [[Johann Heinrich Pestalozzi]].
In 1813. Jullien was jailed due to his opposition to the Empire. Freed during the [[Bourbon Restoration]], he published numerous opposition journals between 1815 and 1817, becoming known in the process as a pedagogue. He corresponded regularly with Pestalozzi, to whom he sent his first three sons, at Yverdon, and became a promoter of the [[Monitorial System]] of education. In 1819 he founded ''Revue encyclopédique''.<ref>[[:fr:Revue encyclopédique]]</ref>
Jullien died in Paris in 1848.
==Marriage and family== In 1801 Jullien married Sophie-Juvence Nioche (died 1832); she bore him six children.
The eldest of the six, Pierre-Adolphe (born [[Amiens]], February 13, 1803 - died 1873) was a technician, later becoming engineer-in-chief of the [[Corps of Bridges and Roads (France)|Corps of Bridges and Roads]]; in this capacity he oversaw construction of the Paris-[[Lyon]] railroad.
Also among the six, their daughter Antoinette-Stéphanie married the dramatist [[Lockroy]] and was the mother of [[Édouard Lockroy]].

Miranda Stevens | height = 6' (1.83 m) | weight = | eye_color = | hair_color = | alias = Mr. 10-1/2 | number_of_films = | website = | years_active = 1971-1988 | death_cause = AIDS }} '''Marc Stevens''' (September 2, 1943 – January 28, 1989), was an [[United States|American]] [[erotic]] performer.{{cite news|last1=Walentis|first1=Al|title=Porn Field Leader: He Promotes Himself|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=N8otAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uKAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3348%2C4961627|accessdate=6 December 2015|publisher=Reading Eagle|date=1976-06-18}} He is sometimes credited as '''Mark '10½' Stevens''' or '''Mark Stevens'''. ==Early life== Marc Stevens was born Mark Kuttner in Brooklyn in 1943. He was the third of four children born to first generation Jewish parents Walter and Hannah. He attended [[Midwood High School]] in Brooklyn.{{cite web|url=http://www.therialtoreport.com/2017/02/19/marc-stevens/ |title=Marc Stevens: ‘Mr. 10 ½’ – The Wild Life and Tragic Fall of the New York Porno Party King – Part 1 |publisher=therialtoreport.com |date= |accessdate=February 19, 2017}} ==Career== Stevens was a pioneering [[sex industry]] figure during the 1970s, in [[New York City]]. He appeared in over 80 [[pornographic movies]]; he also led an [[erotic dance]] [[Dance troupe|troupe]] called Le Clique{{cite book|title=NYC Sex: How New York Transformed Sex in America|date=2002|publisher=Scala Publishers|isbn=1857592778|page=205|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VBsEAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22marc+stevens%22+stripper&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22marc+stevens%22}} and performed in [[live sex show]]s. Tall and lean with a well-defined [[musculature]], he had the nickname "10½" because of the supposed size of his circumcised [[penis]]. He was famously photographed by [[Robert Mapplethorpe]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VCVm7sc5JsC&pg=PA405&lpg=PA405&dq=%22marc+stevens%22+bisexual&source=bl&ots=09jdDT_oHe&sig=-CrB8ggJdlTNugUlPhPtqTkamsc&sa=X&ei=9kMoUKKVHcnY6wGctYHoBg&ved=0CBoQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22marc%20stevens%22%20bisexual&f=false|title=Skinflicks: The Inside Story of the X-Rated Video Industry - David Jennings - Google Boeken|publisher=Books.google.com|accessdate=2013-09-25}} ==Notable films== Notable films featuring Marc Stevens include: * ''[[The Devil in Miss Jones]]'' * ''All about Gloria Leonard'' * ''Michael, Angelo and David'' ==Honorable recognition== Stevens was posthumously inducted into the [[XRCO Hall of Fame]] on April 30, 2008.{{cite news|title=XRCO Announces 2008 Award Winners|url=http://www.avn.com/video/articles/29952.html|accessdate=2008-05-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502062009/http://www.avn.com/video/articles/29952.html | archivedate=2008-05-02}} ==Death== Stevens died of [[AIDS]]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VCVm7sc5JsC&lpg=PA405&dq=%22Marc%20Stevens%22%20actor%20-wikipedia&pg=PA405#v=onepage&q=%22Marc%20Stevens%22%20actor%20-wikipedia&f=false |title=Skinflicks: The Inside Story of the X-Rated Video Industry - David Jennings - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-03}} in 1989, aged 45.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Despite his prominence in the 1970s and the fact he produced two memoirs (long out of print and allegedly [[ghost-written]] by his mother), entitled ''10½!'' and ''Making It Big,''{{cite book|last1=Sullivan|first1=Rebecca|title=Bonnie Sherr Klein's 'Not a Love Story'|date=2014|publisher=University of Toronto Press, Scholarly Publishing Division|page=59|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=atdIBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA40&lpg=PA40&dq=%22marc+stevens%22+stripper&source=bl&ots=QfGh0Si5Vr&sig=Csi64QCcyA95ESax9LCj2qSTOGE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBweHj3cbJAhXEjIMKHShlAY8Q6AEIMTAE#v=onepage&q=%22marc%20stevens%22&f=false}} Stevens has attracted relatively little attention since. ==See also== * [[Golden Age of Porn]] * [[List of male performers in gay porn films]] ==References== ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0828583|name=Marc Stevens}} * {{iafd name|id=MStevens|gender=male|name=Marc Stevens}} * {{afdb name|id=2411|gender=male|name=Marc Stevens}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vDD58bG3iqw Mark Stevens' Party Invites] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stevens, Marc}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:1989 deaths]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in California]] [[Category:American male erotic dancers]] [[Category:American male adult models]] [[Category:American male pornographic film actors]] [[Category:Bisexual male pornographic film actors]] [[Category:Pornographic film actors with HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:Bisexual men]] [[Category:Jewish American male actors]] [[Category:LGBT Jews]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]]

{{Unreferenced|date=May 2011}} [[Image:Martín Luis Guzmán.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Martín Luis Guzmán.]] '''Martín Luis Guzmán Franco''' (October 6, 1887 – December 22, 1976) was a Mexican [[novelist]] and journalist.
==Life== Guzmán was born in [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]]. Along with [[Mariano Azuela]], he is considered a pioneer of the [[revolutionary novel]], a genre inspired by the experiences of the [[Mexican Revolution]] of 1910. His novels ''[[:es:La sombra del caudillo|La sombra del caudillo]]'' (1929) and ''El águila y la serpiente'' (1928) depict the [[Mexican Revolution]] and its political aftermath, both of which the author was familiar with, having contributed both to revolutionary agitation and to the formation of the new revolutionary government.
For several months in 1914, he was under the direct orders of General [[Pancho Villa|Francisco "Pancho" Villa]]. He later wrote a five-volume [[biography]] of Villa, ''Memorias de Pancho Villa'' (1936-1951).
Martin Luis Guzmán died suddenly on December 22, 1976 in [[Mexico City]] due an acute myocardial infarction. His widow Ana West, died seven years after him, on October 21, 1983. She was 95 years old when, after being hospitalized for some days due to an acute bilateral pneumonia, she suffered a cardiac arrest and died.
